text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on May 12 in history:
1809 - Sir Arthur Wellesley (later Duke of Wellington) defeated the French at Oporto, forcing them to retreat from Portugal.
1820 - Florence Nightingale, English nurse and founder of the modern nursing profession, born in Italy. Served as a nurse in Turkey and the Crimea during the Crimean War.
1870 - Manitoba was purchased from the Hudson's Bay Company by the Dominion of Canada and made a province.
1871 - Daniel-Francois-Esprit Auber, French opera composer, died. Famous for developing opera containing spoken as well as sung passages.
1884 - Czech composer Bedrich Smetana, composer of operas including "The Bartered Bride" and "The Brandenburgers in Bohemia", died.
1888 - Britain established protectorates over North Borneo and Brunei.
1918 - Julius Rosenberg born. In 1953 he and his wife, Ethel, became the first U.S. civilians to be executed for espionage, despite a worldwide campaign for mercy.
1926 - Norwegian Roald Amundsen, Italian Umberto Nobile and American Lincoln Ellsworth crossed the North Pole in an airship.
1926 - Jozef Pilsudski led a successful military coup against the government in Poland.
1937 - King George VI of England was crowned at Westminster Abbey in London. The coronation procession was broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation in its first outside broadcast.

1938 - Andrei Amalrik, Soviet author, historian and political dissident, born. He achieved worldwide fame with the publication in 1970 of his provocative essay "Will The Soviet Union Survive Until 1984?".
1943 - In World War Two, all organised Axis resistance in Tunisia ended and the German commander in North Africa, General von Arnim, surrendered.
1949 - The Russian blockade of Berlin officially ended after 11 months with a food convoy driving into the city .
1957 - Erich Von Stroheim, film actor and one of the silent screen's greatest directors, died. Films include "Greed", "The Merry Widow" and "The Wedding March".
1962 - France and independent French-speaking West African states initialled an agreement setting up a West African Monetary Union.
1967 - John Masefield, English poet and, from 1930, poet laureate, died.
1975 - President Ford ordered the U.S. aircraft carrier Coral Sea into the Gulf of Thailand after the Cambodian navy seized the American merchant ship Mayaguez.
1981 - President Benjamin Sheares of Singapore died in office.
1989 - Retired British pilot Jack Mann was kidnapped by Islamic fundamentalists in Beirut. He was the oldest of the Westerners held hostage in Beirut during the Lebanese civil war.
1993 - Franco Nobili, the head of Italy's biggest state firm and Europe's second largest company, IRI, was arrested in Rome after a 15-month corruption investigation.
1994 - British Labour leader John Smith, a canny Scots lawyer with a burning ambition to lead his party back to power after 15 years in opposition, died of a heart attack.
1994 - A token force of Palestinian police crossed the Jordan River in preparation for the end of 27 years of Israeli military rule in a West Bank enclave around Jericho.
1994 - The Senate voted to order President Clinton to seek international agreement on ending the U.N.-mandated arms embargo against the Bosnian Moslems.
